column1: Did you have an injury that knocked out a tooth?#You have TOOTH LOSS.#1#DENTAL EMERGENCY See your dentist or go to the emergency room right away. Keep the tooth moist. It’s best to keep the tooth in your mouth until you get to the dentist or emergency room. The tooth may be saved.
Do you have pain that is specific to one tooth?#1#3#
Have you broken or chipped a tooth
column2: or is the tooth loose in its socket?#Your pain may be from a FRACTURED
column3: CRACKED or LOOSE TOOTH.#1#Save any pieces of the tooth
column5: moist cloth and see your dentist as soon as possible.

column1: Do you feel pain when you eat cold foods or liquids?#Your pain may be from a CAVITY.#1#Make an appointment to see your dentist. Proper brushing and flossing along with fluoride rinses and coatings
Do you have redness or swelling around one or more teeth
column2: in your gums or in your face?#You may have a dental ABSCESS or an INFECTION in a tooth
column3: gums or other tissues.#1#URGENT See your dentist or doctor right away.

column1: Do you have redness and swelling in large areas of your gums
column2: or is the skin inside your mouth peeling?#You may have an infection such as TRENCH MOUTH
column3: GINGIVITIS or PERIODONTITIS. A rare drug reaction
column5: may also cause this.#1#See your dentist or doctor right away. You may be given antibiotics to stop the infection. Over-the-counter pain relievers
column7: may relieve discomfort. Many of these infections can be prevented with proper dental care
column8: such as brushing and flossing regularly.

column4: or do you hear a cracking sound when you bite?#Your pain may be from TEMPOROMANDIBULAR JOINT (TMJ) syndrome
column5: a condition that affects the jaw.#1#Try relaxing your jaw when you are tense or nervous. Stop chewing gum. Try a mild anti-inflammatory medicine
column6: such as ibuprofen. If you don’t get better

column2: please talk to your doctor or your dentist. If you think the problem is serious
column3: call your doctor or your dentist right away.
